After 70 years, the Volkswagen Beetle is retiring. Be a part of history, and share a memory of your Volkswagen Beetle using #TheLastMile to help us say goodbye to an icon. 
If you want your goodbye to be seen by the world, be sure to set your profile to public.

Did you know that @NikeRunning first sold product out of a Type 2 VW Bus? Nike, originally named #BlueRibbonSports is back at it, serving runners coast to coast with new gear, so we decided to upgrade their fleet ⚡️⚡️⚡️
@NikeRunning is taking the ID. BUZZ CARGO wrapped in #BlueRibbonSports livery coast to coast serving runners and dropping limited BRS Nike Cortez '72 and Nike Zoom Pegasus Turbo 2 along the way.

Two global brands #VWxNike coming together to acknowledge their roots and commitments to our future. #DriveBigger

The VW ID. BUZZ CARGO concept vehicle, with fresh #BlueRibbonSports livery is going Coast to Coast with @NikeRunning to help serve runners across the country. Driving Bigger along the way means donating athletic shoes at every stop to Nike’s Reuse-A-Shoe program, which gives worn-out sneakers new life by transforming them into materials used to create running tracks, playing turf surfaces, and athletic gear. Oh and Nike is releasing limited edition sneakers along the way — stay tuned to the Nike #SNKRS app.

Check out the ID. BUZZ CARGO and recycle your shoes at these stops:
⚡️ 10/5 Santa Monica
⚡️ 10/12 Chicago
⚡️ 10/15 NYC

"We are not in this world for ourselves and by ourselves, but we are just here to serve people and to do what’s right and make the world a better place." – Abraham B. "Abe" Jenkins, Jr.
————————————————————————
Through hard work and dedication, Esau and Janie B. Jenkins helped improve the lives of African Americans during the Civil Rights Movement. They provided transportation for the community to help ensure children were educated and adults were employed. They opened local businesses – like a credit union – to help ensure their community had access to financial services. They helped adults learn to read, write, and exercise their civil rights. VW is proud to have collaborated with @HistoricVehicle and @BR_Howard in the preservation of this iconic VW Bus, to help ensure the Jenkins’ story can continue to inspire.

Most vehicles that sit outside unattended for four decades aren’t destined to ever move again. But this 1966 Volkswagen Type 2 isn’t just any Bus – it’s a piece of civil-rights history.
————————————————————————
Through hard work and dedication, Esau and Janie B. Jenkins helped improved the lives of African Americans during the Civil Rights Movement. They provided transportation for the community to help ensure children were educated and adults were employed. They opened local businesses – like a credit union – to help ensure their community had access to financial services. They helped adults learn to read, write, and exercise their civil rights. VW is proud to have collaborated with @HistoricVehicle and @BR_Howard in the preservation of this iconic VW Bus, to help ensure the Jenkins’ story can continue to inspire. 📸: @historicvehicle

“I decided to do anything I can to help people in order to help myself.” – Esau Jenkins
———————————————————————— Through hard work and dedication, Esau and Janie B. Jenkins helped improve the lives of African Americans during the Civil Rights Movement. They provided transportation for the community to help ensure children were educated and adults were employed. They opened local businesses – like a credit union – to help ensure their community had access to financial services. They helped adults learn to read, write, and exercise their civil rights. VW is proud to have collaborated with @historicvehicle and @br_howard in the preservation of this iconic VW Bus, to help ensure the Jenkins’ story can continue to inspire. 📷: @historicvehicle

This VW Bus made history with Esau and Janie B. Jenkins, who spent decades working to help make the country a better place. It continues to make history as the first vehicle archived on the National Historic Vehicle Register under “civil rights.” ————————————————————————
Through hard work and dedication, Esau and Janie B. Jenkins helped improved the lives of African Americans during the Civil Rights Movement. They provided transportation for the community to help ensure children were educated and adults were employed. They opened local businesses – like a credit union – to help ensure their community had access to financial services. They helped adults learn to read, write, and exercise their civil rights. VW is proud to have collaborated with @HistoricVehicle and @BR_Howard in the preservation of this iconic VW Bus, to help ensure the Jenkins’ story can continue to inspire. 📸: Historic Vehicle Association

Sometimes the beauty is in the details. Sometimes it’s in the history. At first sight, all you may see is a #VWBus that hasn’t moved in four decades. But if you dig deeper into its story, you’ll learn that it symbolizes the activism of an incredible couple, who dedicated their lives to the Civil Rights Movement. ————————————————————————

This summer, DC-based restaurant Little Sesame hit the open road with their #VWBus Wilma. Why? To explore the West Coast, embrace the local cuisine, support sustainable farming, and #DriveBigger
Little Sesame is a real VW Owner and we’re proud to have partnered with them for this content.

What is @eatlittlesesame? A #VWBus restaurant that’s celebrating good food and supporting local farmers. Head over to our IGTV to meet the team and their bus, Wilma.

Little Sesame is a real VW Owner and we’re proud to have partnered with them for this content.

Chefs Nick and Ronen met more than a decade ago as cooks in some of NYC’s most acclaimed kitchens. Together, they created @eatlittlesesame, a DC-based restaurant that’s on a mission to #DriveBigger by connecting good farming with good food.

This summer, they drove across the country in their #VWBus, Wilma, to expand their culinary experiences and bring them back home.

Calling all small business Bus owners! Share a photo with #VWBusBusiness for a chance to be featured. 
_______________________________________________________
“I was out driving Klaus, my 2012 Volkswagen Beetle, and I saw a man selling produce from the back of his truck on the side of the road and thought, ‘what a simple, wonderful way to contribute,’” Amelia’s Flower Truck owner Mattie Bush said. “That’s when it clicked, a flower truck! I knew that’s what I wanted to do.” Bush searched high and low online until she found what she was looking for–an Agave Green, beautifully restored 1962 Volkswagen Transporter from a seller in California–and immediately snapped it up. “It was love at first sight,” she said.
